subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... Precisely (that s what I meant by hard to quantify). ... I stress the SRP pretty hard (both at method and class level), since it almost always pays off
messageBody:
Quoting Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...>:
>> I suspect that it's the
>> same reason most developers worry about performance more than good
>> design: it's easier to quantify.
>>
> I think that lack of protection is just easier to see. Lack of cohesion
> requires trained eyes.

Precisely (that's what I meant by hard to quantify).

> I have to admit that every time I teach the
> 'Single Responsibility Principle' I feel a little odd. It's not like
> you can use a check list which tells you whether you're violating it or
> not, you just have to show people enough examples for them to 'get it.'

I stress the SRP pretty hard (both at method and class level), since
it almost always pays off dramatically in terms of code
reduction/reuse, system comprehension, and ease of maintenance, to
name a few things. In contrast, I haven't seen "potential violation of
encapsulation" cause many real problems, at least not in the case of
exposing attributes for test introspection.

> Justice Potter Stewart said (paraphrasing) "I
> may not be able to define obscenity, but I know it when I see it."

Which can work well (but isn't sufficient for) characterizing design.
And man, are there lots of obscene designs out there!

Jeff
